author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Tito’s in a Can,’ Just Add Vodka
description: A portion of the price of Tito’s Handmade Vodka’s stainless steel, 16-ounce can will be donated to charity.
content: With all the canned hard seltzers and ready-to-drink cocktails lining store shelves, Tito’s Handmade Vodka, a corn-based cult favorite from Austin, Texas, has taken a D.I.Y. route with a charity angle. It has introduced a sturdy, fairly slim stainless steel double-walled 16-ounce can containing no drink, with net proceeds donated to charities the company supports. (At checkout you can select one of five charities, like American Farmland Trust and Meals on Wheels America, that will receive at least 25 percent of the price.) We’re long past April 1 but yes, it’s empty, ready for anyone’s preferred libation — presumably made with Tito’s, as suggested on the can.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: The U.S. Will Send Another $1 Billion in Aid to Ukraine.
description: The latest round of aid includes rockets credited with destroying Russian command posts and ammunition depots.
content: The United States will send more ammunition to Ukraine, including rockets for the HIMARS launchers that have been credited with destroying Russian command posts and ammunition depots, the Pentagon said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Choice of Mooncakes for the Mid-Autumn Festival
description: Try Chinese mooncakes in a gift set from Lady M, or Taiwanese-style versions from Té Company in the West Village.
content: It’s a good month before the Mid-Autumn Festival (Sept. 10), also called the Moon Festival, is celebrated in Asia‌n communities. But to avoid less than a full mooncake supply for the occasion, observers often gather theirs in advance. Lady M, the bakery known for elaborate pastries, is ready with Chinese-style mooncakes in a new Glowing Lights Mooncake Gift Set, made in collaboration with Kee Wah Bakery in Los Angeles, a specialist. The set has six cakes in three flavors: Earl Grey, caramel-coffee‌, ‌and purple yam custard. In Taiwan the mooncakes are often different, pale and domed with a red stamp on top. At Té Company, which serves Taiwanese teas, they’re made to order with a filling of mung bean paste, sold in a package of six.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Fashion Suited for Surreal Times
description: Strange proportions, odd materials and clothing shaped like a car — this season, nothing is as it seems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Axios Agrees to Sell Itself to Cox Enterprises for $525 Million
description: The digital media company’s founders, Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen and Roy Schwartz, will continue to run the company.
content: Axios, the digital media company that quickly gained traction since its founding five years ago with its distinctive bulletin-style scoops on the realms of politics, business and technology, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell itself to Cox Enterprises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Kreidler
title: Sacramento Savors Its Underdog Moment
description: The capital city, often overshadowed by San Francisco and Los Angeles, is taking pride in the success of its lower-tier Sacramento Republic F.C. over Major League Soccer teams.
content: SACRAMENTO — A veteran of international soccer, Mark Briggs did not need to be told that his second-division Sacramento Republic Football Club had done something significant, shocking three straight Major League Soccer opponents to advance to the finals of the all-comers U.S. Open Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: How New York City Got Its Fresh Water
description: In “Nineteen Reservoirs,” Lucy Sante recounts the history of a vast network that supplies more than a billion gallons of water a day.
content: Every morning in this newspaper you can, if you dare, check the level of New York City’s reservoir system, which supplies our fresh water, more than a billion gallons a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Anne Saxelby Remembered With a Legacy Fund
description: The owner of Saxelby Cheesemongers was a champion of American-made cheeses. Now her memory will help young people experience sustainable farming.
content: Anne Saxelby, the downtown cheesemonger and promoter of American cheeses who died last year, has been remembered with a fund that offers monthlong paid apprenticeships for young adults to live on sustainable farms. Next month, that organization, the Anne Saxelby Legacy Fund, will host a fund-raiser at the Chelsea Market, featuring 60 of Ms. Saxelby’s favorite chefs, such as Riad Nasr and Lee Hanson of Frenchette, Michael Anthony of Gramercy Tavern, Mario Carbone and Rich Torrisi of Carbone, Lena Ciardullo of Union Square Cafe and Max Ng of Momofuku. Ms. Saxelby, who opened Saxelby Cheesemongers in 2006 and later another store in the Chelsea Market, died in October of a heart condition. She was 40.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: Rescuing Art in Ukraine with Foam, Crates and Cries for Help
description: Many cultural institutions were not prepared to protect their collections and buildings before the Russian invasion, so ad hoc groups of arts workers and leaders stepped in to fill the breach.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — A month after the Russian army invaded Ukraine, the photographer Roman Metelskiy stood on the platform of this western city’s domed Art Nouveau railway station, watching trains full of women and children evacuating from the east. But he was waiting for a carriage from the other direction. This one, from the west, was full of Bubble Wrap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Christopher Flavelle
title: Biden Tours ‘Heartbreaking’ Kentucky Flood Damage
description: The president said he wanted to ensure the area was rebuilt in a way that made it more resilient to natural disasters that he described as a consequence of climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — During his first official trip after recovering from the coronavirus, President Biden flew to eastern Kentucky on Monday and committed federal resources to families whose homes had been condemned or washed away by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Muslims in New Mexico Are Shaken by Possible Targeted Killings
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, August 8, 2022.
content: “Now, I look outside the window and think, ‘Oh, this is the place where my brother was killed. Should we move?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: U.S. Open Commits to Fund-Raising Exhibition Match and $2 Million for Ukraine
description: Unlike at Wimbledon, players from Russia and Belarus will be allowed to compete at the U.S. Open. Whether they play in an exhibition to support relief efforts in Ukraine is another question.
content: For weeks this spring, the leaders of the United States Tennis Association debated whether to allow Russian and Belarusian players to participate in the U.S. Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: The Perfect S’more Is Practically Burned and a Little Salty
description: Potato chips, Nutella and even Peeps can step into this campfire classic, but success lies in its balance of flavors and a healthy char.
content: The campfire s’more is a gooey mess: saccharine, certainly, but also sentimental, stuffed with childhood memories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: A Health Care Bill, Minus Covid
description: The new climate and health legislation does not significantly address the pandemic.
content: On Sunday, after months of painful negotiations, Senate Democrats muscled through a $370 billion climate, tax and health care package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: Decorative Bowls for Odds and Ends
description: Vessels that lessen clutter and bring style to any space.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: How a Last-Minute Lobbying Blitz Watered Down a Climate Bill Tax
description: The new corporate minimum tax is not law yet and is already rife with exceptions for the businesses that might have to pay it.
content: WASHINGTON — An hour after Democrats released the text of their climate and tax legislation, Washington lobbyists for the private equity industry sprang into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young
title: People Flock to South Korean Crypto Event Despite Market Turmoil
description: Falling prices and upheaval in the industry do not appear to have curbed Koreans’ appetite for crypto, blockchain and all things web3.
content: When the South Korean cryptocurrencies Luna and TerraUSD collapsed in May, their failures contributed to a $300 billion loss across the crypto economy; public outcries for Do Kwon, the cryptocurrencies’ creator, to go to jail; and multiple investigations. But that, and a broader “crypto winter” dragging down prices across the industry, do not appear to have curbed South Korea’s appetite for all things web3.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Ann Fennelly
title: I Love My Students, but I Won’t Use a Gun to Protect Them
description: It is difficult to learn when one is always listening for a bullet.
content: OXFORD, Miss. — Before classes start Aug. 22 at the university where I teach English, I’ll locate my new classroom, slip inside and conduct a ritual inspection. It has a practical purpose: ensuring that the chalk board has chalk, the AV has cords, and the desks and chairs are in neat rows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: SoftBank Reports $23 Billion Loss as Tech Investments Plummet
description: Masayoshi Son, the Japanese conglomerate’s founder, said SoftBank would take fewer big risks in the future.
content: The Japanese conglomerate SoftBank reported on Monday its largest-ever quarterly loss, $23.4 billion, driven by poor performance of its flagship tech investments and a weak yen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘A Slow Death’: Egypt’s Political Prisoners Recount Horrific Conditions
description: Many are held in filthy cells, subjected to routine torture and denied lifesaving medications, according to former inmates, their families and lawyers, and rights groups. Some never leave.
content: CAIRO — Every time he appeared before Egyptian prosecutors during his 21 months in detention, Ahmed Abdelnabi, a 61-year-old print shop owner from Alexandria, had a more disturbing story to tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Can Global Shipping Be Fixed? One Regulator Will Try.
description: The Federal Maritime Commission, traditionally obscure, has been cast by Congress and the administration to help lead the campaign to tame inflation.
content: Daniel B. Maffei is at once a crucial player in the campaign to subdue inflation, and a figure virtually unknown outside the confines of his wonky Washington domain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Misha Friedman and Victor Mather
title: Scenes From the Chess Olympiad: Magnus Carlsen Is Still on Top of His Game
description: And the election for president of the International Chess Federation carried overtones of the war in Ukraine.
content: The chess world was left reeling by the surprise announcement last month that its biggest star, Magnus Carlsen, would surrender his world title, citing a lack of motivation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: Bolsonaro Is Afraid of Going to Prison, and He’s Right to Be
description: It’s getting hard to keep track of all the charges against Brazil’s president.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — “I’m letting the scoundrels know,” President Jair Bolsonaro told supporters last year, “I’ll never be imprisoned!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Wang
title: The Heady Nihilism of Kotaro Isaka
description: In “Three Assassins,” the Japanese author’s latest thriller to be translated into English, a corporate assassin isn’t far from a corporate automaton.
content: The killings that take place in “Three Assassins” — and there are many — are disarmingly mundane. Kotaro Isaka describes murder the way a doctor would a surgery: meticulous, but numbly pragmatic. He fixates on the pulpy, tangible procedure of death, the blood, spittle, clatter of knife point against bone. The novel’s central enigma, the Pusher, is defined by his method of pushing his victims in front of moving cars and then vanishing, making the scene look like an accident. But a method quickly becomes a routine, which becomes a straitjacket. And when your clients are a rogues’ gallery of conniving politicians and wealthy dirtbags, a corporate assassin isn’t far from a corporate automaton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: An Italian Newcomer for Murray’s Cheese Shop
description: Cossanella, with an orange-streaked rind, comes from the Piedmont region and has the consistency of soft serve.
content: The bulging orange-streaked rind suggests Époisses from France, but Cossanella, newly imported by Murray’s Cheese Shop, is more delicate. It’s a product of the Alta Langa in the Piedmont region of Italy, an area known for top-flight wines and cheeses like La Tur and Robiola. Cossanella’s rind is washed with annatto — a condiment used for coloring made from the seeds of the achiote tree — providing its rusty hue. The ivory interior has subtle hints of mushroom and verbena, with a satin sheen and the consistency of soft serve. It’s a delectable partner for one of the Alta Langa’s spumantes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Two in Arbery Case Sentenced Again to Life in Prison; Third Man Gets 35 Years
description: The men were convicted of federal hate crimes after state murder convictions in 2021. Their lawyers tried without success to have part of their sentences served in federal prison.
content: ATLANTA — Before the three men convicted of murdering Ahmaud Arbery were sentenced on Monday on federal hate crime charges, they asked a judge to consider not only the length of the sentences, but also the location, with one lawyer arguing that if her client went straight to Georgia’s dangerous state prison system, he would be subject to “vigilante justice.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Elizabeth Williamson
title: Alex Jones’s Text Messages Turned Over to House Jan. 6 Committee
description: The messages only cover a period up to mid-2020, disappointing investigators who hoped they would shed light on the conspiracy theorist’s role in the events leading to the attack on the Capitol.
content: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for plaintiffs who are suing the conspiracy theorist Alex Jones on Monday turned over more than two years’ worth of text messages from Mr. Jones’s phone to the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, including messages that show Mr. Jones was in touch with allies of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: ‘Why Do I Have to Work Twice as Hard Just to Get Noticed?’
description: Sylvia Fowles has been as dominant on the court as Sue Bird, but only one of them is a household name, our columnist writes.
content: Sylvia Fowles is one of the most successful American athletes ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: A cease-fire in Gaza.
content: Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza agreed to a cease-fire late last night, which appeared to hold as of this morning. The move is expected to end a three-day conflict that has killed dozens of Palestinians, destroyed buildings and resulted in the deaths of two key leaders of Islamic Jihad, Gaza’s second-largest militia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘Cheers, Virginia!’ Takes a Boozy Tour Through History
description: The exhibit at the Virginia Museum of History & Culture displays artifacts like George Washington’s fluted drinking glasses, a liquor taxation stamp from 1916 and more.
content: Alcoholic beverages, as they have been woven into the fabric of life in Virginia since the early European settlements, are the subject of a new exhibition at the Virginia Museum of History & Culture in Richmond. Historic details are illustrated by artifacts on display, exploring the need to drink alcoholic beverages because water was unsafe, George Washington’s contribution to American spirits, Prohibition, and modern craft brewing, distilling and winemaking. Among them are George Washington’s fluted drinking glasses, an early 18th century sherry glass, a liquor taxation stamp from 1916, an anti-Prohibition scarf and a 19th century copper still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Yermak
title: In My Homeland, the Smell of Death on a Summer Afternoon
description: In Ukraine, tragedies are a backdrop to everyday existence, piling up in numbers that seem inconceivable, an inescapable reality that feels like the very air in your lungs.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: A Drop in Murders
description: Despite the grim headlines, 2022 is less violent so far than last year.
content: Crime, murder and mass shootings have dominated headlines this year. Just over the weekend, a shooting in Cincinnati wounded nine people, and another in Detroit killed one and wounded four.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Treasury Dept. blacklists crypto platform used in money laundering.
description: The crackdown was the government’s latest effort to rein in the crypto industry.
content: The Treasury Department on Monday prohibited Americans from using the cryptocurrency platform Tornado Cash, saying the service has helped criminals launder more than $7 billion of virtual currencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: A Cease-Fire Holds After a 3-Day Gaza Conflict: Key Takeaways
description: The conflict may have dealt a severe blow to Palestinian Islamic Jihad, the Gaza militant group, and strengthened the hand of Israel’s interim prime minister, Yair Lapid.
content: JERUSALEM — A cease-fire ending three days of fierce cross-border attacks between Israel and a Palestinian militant group in Gaza appeared to be holding on Monday, and life on both sides of the lines began to return to normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Pete Rose Dismisses Questions About Sexual Misconduct
description: After attending an on-field celebration of the 1980 Phillies, Rose refused to answer questions about allegations from a 2017 lawsuit. “It was 55 years ago, babe.”
content: Pete Rose was dismissive Sunday when asked about an accusation that he had sex with a girl under 16 in the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
title: Freed From Prison in China, Taiwan Activist Urges Resistance to Beijing’s Threats
description: Li Ming-che and his wife, who met with Speaker Nancy Pelosi in Taiwan last week, have sought to inspire others not to be intimidated into silence by Beijing.
content: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Li Ching-yu was desperate to send her husband a message.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: In War-Torn Mykolaiv, Ukrainians Search for Informers
description: As the city emerged from a 54-hour lockdown, the governor of the Mykolaiv region declared the operation a success, saying that five people had been arrested.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — The embattled city of Mykolaiv emerged on Monday from a 54-hour lockdown during which officers went door to door in search of collaborators who officials say are responsible for helping Russian forces identify targets for the rockets that pound the city daily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ Dominates the Album and Singles Charts
description: The pop star’s seventh album debuts at No. 1 with the second-biggest opening week of the year, while her song “Break My Soul” climbs to the top of the Hot 100.
content: For her last two solo albums, Beyoncé turned the music business on its head by rewriting the standard marketing playbook. “Beyoncé” (2013) came without warning and had a music video for every song; for “Lemonade” (2016), she teamed with HBO for an hourlong film. Each went straight to No. 1 and became an instant pop-culture moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Lynsey Chutel
title: U.S. Promotes Democracy in Africa as Rival Nations Expand Influence
description: The Biden administration says the push will bolster African and American interests, including the ability of the United States to compete against China and Russia.
content: PRETORIA, South Africa — The United States has been grappling with the growing influence of China, Russia and Middle Eastern nations across Africa, a situation made more acute in recent months by the competition to win partners in the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: In Wisconsin, G.O.P. Voters Demand the Impossible: Decertifying 2020
description: Donald Trump’s supporters have turned anger over his defeat two years ago, and the false notion that it can still be reversed, into central campaign issues ahead of the battleground state’s primary.
content: SHEBOYGAN, Wis. — When she started her campaign for governor of Wisconsin, former Lt. Gov. Rebecca Kleefisch, a Republican, acknowledged that President Biden had been legitimately elected.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Aug. 8, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 8, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Regan Stephens
title: In Search of Mexican Pizza
description: Taco Bell may have made the name famous, but this pizza — made with leavened dough and traditional Mexican ingredients — has become a genre all its own.
content: PHILADELPHIA — On a sticky day in late June, Margarita Jeronimo and Aaron del Rosario assembled a feast on a picnic table outside Rosario’s, their restaurant on a quiet corner in South Philadelphia. The procession started with tamarind and hibiscus aguas frescas, followed by tortilla chips and hand-painted bowls filled with green and red salsas, and finally, pizza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ziegler
title: A Chaotic Sprint to the Finish for the W.N.B.A. Season
description: Six teams are fighting for the final three playoff spots with only one week left.
content: The Chicago Sky, the reigning champions, are assured of one of the top two spots in the upcoming W.N.B.A. playoffs. The rebuilding Indiana Fever are the only team out of contention. Everything else is up for grabs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Chad’s Military Junta and Rebels Sign a Deal, but a Main Player Is Missing
description: The accord paves the way for national reconciliation talks and democratic elections. However, it was snubbed by the main rebel group responsible for the death of Chad’s previous leader.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — Chad’s military government and more than 40 rebel groups signed a cease-fire agreement on Monday in Qatar, paving the way for reconciliation talks later this month as the Central African nation seeks a way out of a troubled political transition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Varenikova
title: Rumors spread quickly in wartime Ukraine.
description: While seemingly harmless, these tales may have their origins in Russian propaganda, according to analysts monitoring Russian disinformation campaigns in Ukraine.
content: They lived in an abandoned house in a forest next to a small village. They survived on mushrooms and berries. And it took months after the Russian Army retreated for the Ukrainian police to finally capture them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Zorich
title: ‘What a Horrible Place This Would Have Been’
description: Archaeologists found the remains of 14 soldiers who died in a pivotal Revolutionary War battle — a fresh reminder of the violence of war.
content: This spring, a team of archaeologists and volunteers began painstakingly digging into the history of Fort Mercer, a Revolutionary War fortification on the Delaware River that is now the centerpiece of Red Bank Battlefield Park in National Park, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rikki Novetsky, Diana Nguyen, Lynsea Garrison, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Patricia Willens, M.J. Davis Lin, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: The Alex Jones Verdict and the Fight Against Disinformation
description: What is the significance of the defamation case against America’s most prominent conspiracy theorist?
content: This episode contains descriptions of distressing scenes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why the Rent Is So High
description: New York City faces a housing crisis that’s making it harder for middle- and low-income people to live here.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at why affordable apartments are in such short supply in New York. We’ll also look at a new player in the Mets’ lineup who’s hard to miss — and who, in only two weeks, has become a fan favorite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Tom Mashberg
title: Investigators Say Collector Had Suspect Art and Lots of Chutzpah
description: The investigators say Georges Lotfi invited them to his storage space because he did not think they would suspect that the antiquities he kept there were stolen, an accusation he denies.
content: For years, Georges Lotfi made himself a valuable source of information to prosecutors investigating the global trafficking of looted antiquities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Strip-Searches of Children by London Police Are Called ‘Deeply Concerning’
description: A report from England’s children’s commissioner on Monday found that 650 children, including a disproportionate number of young Black boys, were subjected to the practice.
content: LONDON — Hundreds of children were strip-searched in London by the police over a three-year period, according to a report released on Monday by Britain’s top official for children, who said she was “unconvinced” that the authorities were sufficiently judicious in employing the invasive practice in light of the potential harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Hong
title: $15 French Fries and $18 Sandwiches: Inflation Hits New York
description: As food prices rise at the fastest rate in decades, it’s become more expensive to eat and drink in New York City.
content: This was supposed to be a summer of long-awaited celebrations in New York City, the return of a packed calendar full of birthday dinners and happy hours. But New Yorkers are confronting sticker shock everywhere they look, whether they’re shopping for barbecue supplies at the grocery store, ordering a beer after work or grabbing a late-night slice of pizza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francis Wilkinson
title: We Will All End Up Paying for Someone Else’s Beach House
description: As extreme weather events compound, the obvious perils of waterfront living are growing both more obvious and more perilous.
content: A video of a North Carolina beach house being dismembered by a voracious ocean was a viral hit this spring. But it won’t be long before the novelty wears off. As sea level rises and storm surges grow more intense, beach towns on every coast of the United States will soon be sacrificing more real estate to Poseidon. A 2018 study by the Union of Concerned Scientists found that more than 300,000 coastal homes, currently worth well over $100 billion, are at risk of “chronic inundation” by 2045.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: Bert Fields, Lawyer to the Hollywood Elite, Dies at 93
description: A master dealmaker, he had as clients Madonna, Michael Jackson, Tom Cruise, the Beatles and many others, becoming something of a celebrity himself.
content: Bert Fields, the colorful and canny dean of Hollywood lawyers whose services were called on by superstars and studios alike knowing they would get a no-holds-barred defense and all but assured of some measure of victory, died on Sunday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: What’s Your Breastfeeding Story? We Want to Hear From You.
description: If you’re a parent trying to breastfeed — with all the highs and lows that brings — we want to hear your story.
content: The American Academy of Pediatrics recently issued new breastfeeding recommendations encouraging women to breastfeed for two years or beyond, if doing so is “mutually desired” by moms and their babies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Your Pandemic Puppy Was Not a Mistake
description: Living with an animal of another species has never been trouble-free. But the rewards are extravagant.
content: NASHVILLE — It was a Saturday night, close to midnight, when the weird little cough erupting from our dog Rascal’s mouth stopped being a cough and turned into dramatic hacking. My husband and I looked at each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg and Charlie Savage
title: Biden Appeared to Overstate the Role of Al Qaeda’s Leader
description: Terrorism experts were surprised by the president’s descriptions of Ayman al-Zawahri, who was killed in a U.S. drone strike.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — In announcing last week that the leader of Al Qaeda, Ayman al-Zawahri, had been killed in a U.S. drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan, President Biden described the long-sought terrorist as “a mastermind” behind the U.S.S. Cole bombing in 2000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Why the Soothsayers Are So Puzzled by This Year’s Midterms
description: People who have predicted election after election are scratching their heads about this one, as Election Day approaches.
content: Doug Sosnik is the kind of political analyst who likes to figure out the results of the next election well in advance — it’s just how he’s wired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Ukraine Disowns an Olympic Champion Who Skated in Russia
description: Viktor Petrenko, who won a gold medal at the 1992 Winter Games, has been shunned by Ukrainian figure skating officials — and by President Volodymyr Zelensky — after performing in Sochi, Russia.
content: As Russia began its invasion of Ukraine in February, Viktor Petrenko, one of Ukraine’s most visible Olympic champions, posted the message “NO WAR” to his Instagram account. Days later, Petrenko’s daughter said her father had been stranded in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, where he was taking shelter after returning from a commemoration of his 1992 Olympic figure skating title that had been held in his hometown, Odesa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Yermak
title: For Ukrainians in Donbas, tragedy is the backdrop to everyday existence.
description: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.
content: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Did Democrats Just Save Civilization?
description: On climate, Biden got almost everything he wanted.
content: They really did it. The Inflation Reduction Act, which is mainly a climate change bill with a side helping of health reform, passed the Senate on Sunday; by all accounts it will easily pass the House, so it’s about to become law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: In Lawsuits, Ex-Employees Offer Harsh Portrait of Project Veritas
description: One former employee described the conservative group as having a “highly sexualized” atmosphere where drinking and drug use were commonplace.
content: The conservative group Project Veritas has for years sought to embarrass political opponents and members of media organizations by surreptitiously recording them and publicizing their private communications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: At Mostly Mozart Concerts, Casual Vibes and High Musical Values
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra offered a series of breezy but focused programs at Lincoln Center, filled with treats big and small.
content: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra bears the name of a festival that no longer exists, but over the last three weeks, it played 12 concerts that showed it still has a place in the new creative landscape at Lincoln Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Olivia Newton-John, Pop Singer and ‘Grease’ Star, Dies at 73
description: She amassed No. 1 hits, chart-topping albums and four records that sold more than two million copies each. More than anything else, she was likable, even beloved.
content: Olivia Newton-John, who sang some of the biggest hits of the 1970s and ’80s while recasting her image as the virginal girl next door into a spandex-clad vixen — a transformation reflected in miniature by her starring role in “Grease,” one of the most popular movie musicals of its era — died on Monday at her ranch in Southern California. She was 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: When Sexual Liberation Is Oppressive
description: On Nona Willis Aronowitz’s “Bad Sex: Truth, Pleasure and an Unfinished Revolution.”
content: The conclusion of Louise Perry’s “The Case Against the Sexual Revolution: A New Guide to Sex in the 21st Century,” which was published in Britain in June and will arrive here next month, is titled “Listen to Your Mother.” Arguing that young women need to protect themselves from a sexual culture that treats them as disposable, Perry urges them to draw from the accumulated wisdom of previous generations. Feminism, she writes, “needs to rediscover the mother, in every sense.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Follow the Scent of Cardamom to Smor Bakery
description: Near the restaurant Smor in the East Village, this bakery offers pastries, packaged goods and sandwiches.
content: Smor, a bright little Scandinavian-inspired restaurant in the East Village, now has its own bakery a few steps away. The Danish owners of both, Sebastian Perez and Sebastian Bangsgaard, had plans for it all along but the pandemic interfered. Their baker is Rowan Gill from Bien Cuit and Leo. The new bakery adds to New York’s growing supply of Nordic bakeries and their wealth of fragrant cardamom buns. It also offers cinnamon buns, swirled Danish tebirkes poppy seed rolls and breads like a dense rye loaf, a savory bread studded with Castelvetrano olives, and sourdough rolls that are the foundations for assorted sandwiches. There are 15 seats, and shelves laden with packaged goods like tinned fish, jams and homemade sauces and mustard herring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘The Princess’ and ‘Password’
description: HBO airs a new documentary on the life and death of Princess Diana. And NBC brings back a game show.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Aug. 8 — 14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ex-Officer to Serve Time for Failing to Act in Excessive Force Arrest
description: The sentencing of Daria Jalali over her failure to intervene comes two years after a woman with dementia was mistreated by another officer in the Loveland Police Dept. in Colorado.
content: A former Colorado police officer was sentenced to 45 days in jail and three years of probation on Friday for failing to intervene during the arrest of a 73-year-old woman with dementia who was assaulted by a different police officer in June 2020, a law firm representing the officer confirmed on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: A Sparsely Populated Island, a Marital Spat and a Missing Husband
description: Johanna Mo’s new novel, “The Shadow Lily,” is a solid police procedural that brims with twists, turns and surprising revelations.
content: The mark of a promising series is that each installment can stand alone, and readers can begin with any book. It’s too early to say if this will hold for Johanna Mo’s Island Murders cycle, just two books strong, but THE SHADOW LILY (Penguin Books, 418 pp., paper, $16.99) is a solid police procedural that invited me onto the sparsely populated Baltic island of Öland, where nights are pitch-black and villages “sometimes consisted of no more than a few houses.” Like the first book in the series, “The Night Singer,” it’s capably translated from the Swedish by Alice Menzies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: California Fire and Floods Turn a River to ‘Sludge,’ Killing Thousands of Fish
description: Flash floods last week pushed burned soil, rocks and downed timber into the river, killing off, according to local tribal leaders, thousands of fish.
content: As a deadly fire continued to burn last week in the Klamath National Forest in Northern California, Kenneth Brink, a local fisherman, counted dead fish in a river that had turned to the consistency of “chocolate milk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Subverting a Preppy Classic
description: Customized L.L. Bean tote bags have become blank canvases for a contemporary sense of humor.
content: When Gracie Wiener ordered a canvas Boat and Tote bag through the L.L. Bean website in July 2021, she filled out the “add monogram” field with the word “psycho” instead of her initials. “I think it’s funny to wear your best, or worst, qualities on your sleeve,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China’s New Military Drills Near Taiwan
description: Also, a moving dispatch from Ukraine and the dire outlook for Afghanistan.
content: Just a day after ending its largest-ever military exercises near Taiwan, China announced new operations in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss
title: It’s Never Too Late to Take Up Water Polo
description: Mark Braly, 86, has spent the last decade playing a particularly challenging team sport. Is he good? No — but that’s not the point.
content: It’s Never Too Late is a series about people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Are You Feeling About Back-to-School This Year?
description: Tell us about it.
content: As summer begins to wind down, many families across the U.S. are preparing for a new school year. Some students have already returned to class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: The U.N. secretary general warns that attacks on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear complex could be ‘suicidal.’
description: The remarks by António Guterres came two days after he called for global nuclear disarmament at a commemoration of the 77th anniversary of the U.S. nuclear bombing of Hiroshima.
content: The United Nations secretary general, António Guterres, on Monday condemned the fighting around the vast Zaporizhzhia nuclear power complex in southern Ukraine, saying that any attack on a nuclear facility is “suicidal.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Another Gaza Conflict, but With a Difference: Hamas Sat It Out.
description: In the weekend battle with Israel, Hamas left the fighting to Islamic Jihad, another militant group, highlighting differences between them over how best to combat Israel.
content: The brief weekend conflict over Gaza had a grimly familiar outcome: dozens of Palestinians killed, including militant leaders as well as children, and scores of homes damaged or destroyed, most by Israeli airstrikes but some from Palestinian misfires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy M. Davies
title: An Argument for Calling Your Mother
description: Lynne Tillman’s taut memoir of caring for an aging parent runs an emotional gamut.
content: With the rights of mothers and would-be mothers and would-rather-not-be mothers first under threat, and now under open ambush, who can blame writers and publishers for voting with their offerings? Mothers are having a moment. Novels about mothers, memoirs by and about them, essays on mothering with and without trauma, with or without dollops of white space between paragraphs. Mothers for most every palate. Yet the observant reader will probably have noticed that mothers have never been in short supply. Every idiot seems to have one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and David Guttenfelder
title: In a Summer of Feints, Russia and Ukraine Try to Predict Enemy’s Next Move
description: Ukraine says that announcing a planned offensive on the southern front has paid off in the eastern Donbas region, as both sides deploy forces based on guessing each other’s next moves.
content: SLOVIANSK, Ukraine — At one point on the front line, Ukrainian soldiers advanced by creeping on their bellies 50 yards at a time, digging new trenches at every stop. Elsewhere, soldiers with the 93rd Brigade captured about three miles of wheat fields — and a Russian tank. Another unit liberated a village last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Lewis
title: David McCullough, Best-Selling Explorer of America’s Past, Dies at 89
description: His research — on Adams, Truman and so much more — was deep, his writing was lively, and his narrator’s voice in documentary films was familiar to millions.
content: David McCullough, who was known to millions as an award-winning, best-selling author and an appealing television host and narrator with a rare gift for recreating the great events and characters of America’s past, died on Sunday at his home in Hingham, Mass., southeast of Boston. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Mandela Barnes Is Already Looking Past Wisconsin’s Democratic Primary
description: Mr. Barnes, Wisconsin’s lieutenant governor, consolidated his party’s support in his bid to take on Ron Johnson, one of the most vulnerable Republicans in the Senate.
content: Lt. Gov. Mandela Barnes of Wisconsin is entering Tuesday’s Democratic primary for a Senate seat as the clear favorite to take on Senator Ron Johnson and is already sharpening his attacks against the Republican incumbent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles History (in a Half-Shell)
description: After nearly 40 years and a new Netflix film, a look at what continues to make these cartoon heroes so appealing.
content: There’s a great episode of “The Simpsons” in which Roger Myers Jr., a cartoon producer who runs the hit show “Itchy & Scratchy,” attempts to introduce a new character into the series to rejuvenate declining ratings. Poochie, the sunglasses-wearing, surfboard-carrying dog the studio comes up with, is “a dog with attitude,” explains one of the network executives pushing the idea. “He’s edgy, he’s in your face. You’ve heard the expression ‘let’s get busy’? Well, this is a dog who gets biz-zay. Consistently and thoroughly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti, Alan Feuer and Alexandra Berzon
title: Michigan Officials Detail a Brazen Voting Machine Scheme by Trump Supporters
description: Revelations of possible meddling have set off a political tsunami in a critical battleground state, as the attorney general seeks an independent inquiry into her likely rival on the ballot this fall.
content: In early 2021, with the turmoil of a bitterly contested presidential contest still fresh, several election clerks in Michigan received strange phone calls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolyn Wilke
title: Do Spiders Dream of Eight-Legged Sheep?
description: Researchers found jumping spiders, known for their acrobatic hunting, exhibiting signs of R.E.M. sleep, but it is unknown whether they dream, or even sleep.
content: By day, jumping spiders hunt their prey, stalking and pouncing like cats. When the lights go down, these pea-sized predators hang out — and maybe their minds spin dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘The Devil Wears Prada’ Review: An Adaptation That Needs Tailoring
description: The new Elton John-Shaina Taub musical, based on the popular film about a fashion-world ingénue and her demanding boss, isn’t yet ready-to-wear.
content: CHICAGO — A movie-to-musical that wants to have its cake and eat it, too, and still fit into a sample size, “The Devil Wears Prada,” opened at the James M. Nederlander Theater here on Sunday. With music by the rock god Elton John and lyrics by the Off-Broadway sweetheart Shaina Taub (“Suffs”), it had seemed poised to set a trend or two.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins
title: The Taliban’s Dangerous Collision Course With the West
description: After barring girls from high school — and harboring an Al-Qaeda leader — the regime now risks jeopardizing the billions of dollars of global aid that still keeps Afghans alive.
content: Afghanistan’s ministry of education sits on a chaotic thoroughfare in downtown Kabul, not far from the presidential palace. When I visited this May, I was able to walk straight into The main building without having to state my business or undergo more than a light frisk. The country’s four-​decade civil war is at its lowest ebb in years, and many of the capital’s draconian security measures have been scaled back by the new Taliban government. The crowds of petitioners inside the ministries have changed, as well: Women are seldom seen, and the traditional garb of robe and trousers has become nearly ubiquitous among men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: ‘No Drama’ Compost? N.Y.C. Is Expanding Food and Yard Waste Pickup
description: The city will pilot automatic, optional curbside pickup across Queens after lagging behind promises to collect compost.
content: What happens to food scraps in the garbage is both gross (rats, garbage juice) and weighty (methane emissions, climate crisis). In New York, the fate of old food has recently inflamed passions and caused a political stink.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Along a Subway Line’s 31 Miles, Nagging Crime Fears Test Riders’ Resolve
description: Ridership is down, even though crime levels have stayed the same. Some New Yorkers who ply the longest subway route say the city feels unmoored.
content: At 31 miles long, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s A train traverses New York City, from the thriving Dominican enclave of Washington Heights to the Financial District, from rugged East New York to beachy Far Rockaway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Trump Asked Aide Why His Generals Couldn’t Be Like Hitler’s, Book Says
description: The former president once asked his chief of staff why his military leadership couldn’t be more like the German generals who had reported to Adolf Hitler, according to an excerpt.
content: WASHINGTON — President Donald J. Trump told his top White House aide that he wished he had generals like the ones who had reported to Adolf Hitler, saying they were “totally loyal” to the leader of the Nazi regime, according to a forthcoming book about the 45th president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.
content: The recent renovation of this house was inspired by traditional Spanish-style construction and by the site, where 100-year-old oaks and drought-tolerant plants grow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: The Guessing Game on the Front
description: Ukraine and Russia are in a quandary over where to concentrate their forces.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs and Tom Mashberg
title: U.S. Returns 30 Looted Antiquities to Cambodia
description: At a ceremony in Manhattan, federal officials said the artifacts had been stolen by organized looters who sold them through an art dealer who was later indicted on smuggling charges.
content: American and Cambodian officials urged museums and private collectors on Monday to investigate the origins of their Khmer art to determine whether it had been looted, and the officials demonstrated the pervasiveness of such thefts at an event that celebrated the return of 30 antiquities to Cambodia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Is on a Roll That Any President Would Relish. Is It a Turning Point?
description: White House aides say the string of victories compares favorably to the two-year legislative record of most any other modern president.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden arrived at Air Force One on Monday with a jaunty step, a playful manner and a huge grin. “Feeling great,” he declared. He meant physically, having finally ended his lengthy bout with Covid-19, but he could have been talking about his presidency writ large.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emi Nietfeld
title: Exercise Was the Perfect Coping Mechanism, Until It Wasn’t
description: I believed I’d found the cure for the depression and trauma that had plagued me for years: Start running and just don’t stop.
content: When I was a junior in college, I joined the rowing team. The unthinkably expensive boats gliding down the Charles River enchanted me. But I was also drawn to something else: I’d heard crew was brutal. In the aftermath of a chaotic adolescence, I felt constantly on edge. What more wholesome way was there to burn off the feeling of hot poison in my veins than with a movie montage of fitness, pounding up stadium stairs while wearing a visor? In a tunnel of fire, I hoped to find relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Mike Ives
title: China’s Military Drills and Other Tensions With Taiwan, Explained
description: China’s military announced new exercises near Taiwan, a day after concluding four days of drills that simulated a blockade of the island.
content: China said on Monday that it would hold new drills near Taiwan, a sign that Beijing may keep up a drumbeat of military pressure on the island after conducting its largest-ever exercises in the area in retaliation for Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman
title: In an Unequal Economy, the Poor Face Inflation Now and Job Loss Later
description: Americans with low incomes are pulling back from buying even as their richer counterparts keep spending — with potentially big consequences.
content: For Theresa Clarke, a retiree in New Canaan, Conn., the rising cost of living means not buying Goldfish crackers for her disabled daughter because a carton costs $11.99 at her local Stop & Shop. It means showering at the YMCA to save on her hot water bill. And it means watching her bank account dwindle to $50 because, as someone on a fixed income who never made much money to start with, there aren’t many other places she can trim her spending as prices rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Laundry Hampers
description: The best ones make dealing with dirty laundry a whole lot easier.
content: How crucial is your laundry hamper? It can make or break your plans to control clutter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: Maps in Four States Were Ruled Illegal Gerrymanders. They’re Being Used Anyway.
description: A Supreme Court shift, frowning on changes close to elections, gives House Republicans a big advantage in November.
content: WASHINGTON — Since January, judges in Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and Ohio have found that Republican legislators illegally drew those states’ congressional maps along racial or partisan lines, or that a trial very likely would conclude that they did. In years past, judges who have reached similar findings have ordered new maps, or had an expert draw them, to ensure that coming elections were fair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Electric Cars Too Costly for Many, Even With Aid in Climate Bill
description: Battery-powered vehicles are considered essential to the fight against climate change, but most models are aimed at the affluent.
content: Policymakers in Washington are promoting electric vehicles as a solution to climate change. But an uncomfortable truth remains: Battery-powered cars are much too expensive for a vast majority of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris and Scott McIntyre
title: Embarrassing, Uncomfortable and Risky: What Flying Is Like for Passengers Who Use Wheelchairs
description: To better understand the obstacles faced by wheelchair users, The Times sent a reporter and a photographer to document one man’s plane trip. Here’s what they saw.
content: Charles Brown has always loved flying. He loves the steady roar of the engine beneath him as the plane rises high above a shrinking ground, turning houses into small blocks of color and cars into floating specks of light below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Mets Strengthen Their N.L. East Lead
description: The Mets won four of five games in a crucial series with the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.
content: The Mets won four of five games in a crucial series with the Atlanta Braves at Citi Field.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $4 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.
content: A Spanish-style retreat in Santa Barbara, a grand 1933 home in the Hollywood Hills and a Mediterranean-style house in Long Beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Promises Federal Aid to Rebuild After Flooding in Kentucky
description: President Biden toured parts of Kentucky hit by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history, pledging federal resources toward rebuilding efforts and to families who lost their homes.
content: President Biden toured parts of Kentucky hit by some of the worst flooding in the state’s history, pledging federal resources toward rebuilding efforts and to families who lost their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Blinken Details Push to Bolster Democracy in Africa
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States would collaborate with African nations to promote democratic governance across the continent.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said the United States would collaborate with African nations to promote democratic governance across the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Authorities Seek Public’s Help in Investigation of Albuquerque Killings
description: The authorities appealed to the public for help as they sought the person or people who killed four Muslim men in Albuquerque.
content: The authorities appealed to the public for help as they sought the person or people who killed four Muslim men in Albuquerque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Melissa Clark brought us four recipes for upside-down cake, perfect for overripe fruit from the market.
content: Good morning. Melissa Clark recently went big on upside-down cakes  in The Times, and now that’s all I want to make: peach upside-down cake (above); pineapple upside-down cake with pecans; berry upside-down cake; banana upside-down cake. They’re relatively easy to put together and are perfect for those of us who buy too much at the farmers’ market and wince at the sight of aging fruit on the counter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Climate Bill, No Thanks to the G.O.P.
description: Readers decry the united Republican opposition and “deal making behind closed doors.” Also: A new “axis of evil”; nuclear dangers; an Idaho housing crisis.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
